publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

monogr.title: Nevv epigrams, and a satyre. VVritten by Ios: Martyn, a wel-wisher to study
monogr.author: Martyn, Joseph

div.head: A Poeticall insinuation.
div.l: MY Muse, that for these sixe yeeres day was mute,
And vnacquainted with those wits acute,
That doe frequent Pernassus sacred Hill,
And of that horse-bred Font doe drinke their fill:
Addrest like others, to auoid suspition
Of each inuectiue Satyrs disposition,
Stept forth into the woods, vnseene, (desire
Presses on those whom Reason bids retire,)
Twixt doubt, and hope, much fearing, daring more,
At length, resolu'd some Deity t'implore▪
Vnder Conduct of whose ador'd protection,
Shee might haue some excuse for imperfection▪
And (being of a high aspiring thought▪)
Left those Semi-dei, and soar'd aloft.
And to that great Apollo shepherds God,
She pow'rd her vowes▪ at which he seem'd to nod.
Or at the least (poore Muse) she wisht so much,
Fond hope, what we desire doth promise such,
Yet herewith all content she doth proceed,
Fearing no lesse, then hoped happy speed.
